title: Tuesday, 18th July, 2017

Gate Ventures PLC (“Gate” or the “Company”) announces that Sarah Ferguson, Duchess of York (“Duchess of York”) has been appointed to the board of Gate (“Board”), as an executive director, with effect from 4 July 2017. Sarah has been appointed primarily to assist the Company with the branding and marketing of its products and productions. For 10 years, Sarah was a successful spokesperson for Weight Watchers International where she was a key ambassador of the company and as such was instrumental in increasing revenue figures during her tenure.

I don't need their stinking $200k and generous bonus.

BE11:09am

(No offence, ROTR.)

Yeah, no offence

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Where should we begin, then?

PM11:10am

Erm, not Carillion. I'm bored with Carillion

BE11:10am

Ditto.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

There's inflation? If we want to go macro?

BE11:11am

Sterling pinged higher, rates expectations pinged lower.

PM11:11am

Suddenly, almost nothing's moving (except Carillion)

11:11 am
PM11:11am

But yes, we can do inflation

PM11:12am

Barclay calls it ' soft core'

BE11:12am

The news being that inflation eased back a bit in June

11:12 am
PM11:12am

The June print - Broad-based weakness: Headline CPI inflation came in weaker than our below-consensus forecast, falling to 2.6% y/y in June from 2.9% y/y in May. The drop was led by volatile and core components. Core inflation declined much more than we and the consensus had projected (2.6%), falling 0.2pp to 2.4%.

PM11:12am

Core services recovery continues to lose steam - At the core level, services inflation was the main source of weakness. Recreational and cultural prices printed 1.5% y/y in June, correcting a good portion of the May rise when they jumped to 2.3% from 1.0% in April supported by notoriously volatile games, toys and hobbies, particularly computer games. Elsewhere, services inflation moved largely sideways, supporting our view that most of the recovery in non-tradable prices appears to be behind. Of note, housing services inflation declined to (1.2%), hitting for second time in six months the lowest level since October 2010.

No great insights from core goods prices - Also non energy industrial goods (NEIG) prices did contribute to the low core inflation print. NEIG fell to 2.0% from 2.2% previously. However, the decline was almost entirely driven by the two most volatile components, semi-durables and non-durables falling to 1.7% and 1.2% from 2.1% and 1.6% before, which are much more volatile than durables prices (still down 0.1pp to 2.8% though). Hence, we do not rule out the NEIG could revert somewhat in the coming months, making it difficult to gauge from the June data if, as we do continue to expect, most of past currency depreciation has actually been passed through to core goods prices.

PM11:12am

Food edged up while energy continues to come off – Processed food prices increased to 1.6% from 1.3% previously, while unprocessed food declined 2.9% from 3.0%, taking food inflation at 2.7% from 2.5%. Fuel and lubricants inflation dropped to 4.1% from 7.5%.

RPI slightly softer than expected as the RPI/CPI basis widened – The RPI-CPI basis widened in June, whereas we had expected it to hold steady at 0.8pp. Housing Depreciation was relatively stable compared with May, having been a source of significant volatility previously. The widening in the basis was driven by a range of components.

11:12 am
PM11:13am

So we get cheap money for longer. Thumbs up

BE11:13am

Here we are in chart form:

BE11:13am

11:13 am
BE11:13am

As HSBC says ............

BE11:13am

This month's decline was not very broad-based and was partly driven by volatile categories such as audio-visual equipment and clothing. We think that the effect of weakness in the pound on import prices has further to run. That is especially the case because our inflation outlook hinges on our FX strategists' forecasts, which see GBP:USD and EUR:GBP ending this year at 1.20 and 1.00, respectively. For this reason, our forecast is for CPI inflation to run well above the BoE's 2% target throughout next year.

BE11:14am

How much audio-visual equipment does a person buy in the average month?

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Nevertheless, today's data removed some ammunition from the hawks on the MPC. Committee members
Ian McCafferty and Michael Saunders, who voted to hike rates in June, have been fretting about the
undesirable combination of above-target inflation and near-full employment (with the jobless rate at
4.5%, in line with the Bank's estimate of equilibrium). Today's inflation print offers the MPC extra
breathing space, not least because CPI inflation has edged away from the 3% mark, the point at which the
Governor needs to write a letter to the Chancellor explain the 'overshoot' of the inflation target.

BE11:14am

Before today's release, we had already been arguing that recent hawkish noises from the MPC were
unlikely to last (see Is the 'Old Lady' for turning?, 30 June). Over the past fortnight, this view has been
bolstered by two developments. First, Ben Broadbent, the Deputy Governor responsible for Monetary
Policy, said last week that he is 'not ready' to raise rates. This is important because Mr Broadbent has
been seen as a key 'swing' voter on the Committee. Looking to the 3 August MPC meeting, Ian
McCafferty and Michael Saunders might remain the only two members voting for a hike. Second, we
have seen a raft of weak activity data in recent weeks, leading us to halve our Q2 growth forecast from
0.4% to 0.2% q-o-q (see A bad week of UK data, 7 July).
Today's data is a third key development which might weaken hawkish moves at the BoE. With the MPC's
hawks still in the minority, growth slowing and Brexit uncertainties looming, our forecast is for Bank
Rate to remain at 0.25% for the whole of this year and next.

Ladies and gentlemen,

The British Pound was today AGAIN victim of a leak of government data! When will you finally STOP THIS CRIME?

Enogh is enough!!!!!!!

BE11:16am

Oh, really? I've heard this theory placed hypothetically by many people but have yet to be swung by the evidence.

PM11:16am

11:16 am
PM11:17am

Which I won't name

PM11:17am

Here he is from last month

PM11:17am

Dear all,

When will you finally catch the criminal leakers of UK government data?

Even the U.S. press has meanwhile published articles which clearly describe that there are leaks! A way to find out is actually very easy:

https://www.wsj.co...est-yes-1493182801

The currency market is one that reacts to these sort of leaks beforehand. Analysis of Foreign Exchange volume numbers on professional platforms like EBS should give you an idea which parties have bought/sold unusual amounts of currency (in this case GBP) before the release of the figures.

Today was AGAIN one of these leaking days referred to in the WSJ article!

When will the FCA and Serious Fraud Office finally react and investigate?

Regards,

11:18 am
PM11:19am

Anyway, British Land called for on the right

PM11:19am

We should respond, maybe

BE11:19am

I guess. Here's the release:

11:19 am
BE11:19am

British Land has today repurchased a total of 1,000,000 shares at an average price of 1,369.8p per share. British Land expects to make further purchases, together totalling up to £250million over the next 12 months.
Stephen Hester, British Land Chief Executive, commented: "We are focussed on shareholder value and generally expect to deploy our capital in physical assets from which to target superior returns relative to peers. However, we believe the gap that has recently opened between sector share prices and real asset values is too gloomy in its implied view of our prospects.
"We continue to see profitable opportunities to invest capital, both in our development programme and selective asset acquisitions and will press ahead with these as they arise. We have also completed or contracted on well over £1billion of asset sales since our March 31 fiscal year end with more in the pipeline. This follows £3.7billion of asset recycling last year. Our REIT status is a significant value creator in both purchases and sales which we will continue to leverage.
“Our balance sheet remains efficient and our property sales allow us capacity to profitably reinvest in our business both directly and via the share repurchases we are announcing today. We intend to remain flexible in relation to the timing and amount of share buybacks, taking account, inter alia, of our share price, property market conditions, balance sheet leverage and competing investment opportunities.
"British Land’s regular dividend payments (now paid quarterly) are running at a level nearly 100% above 2005/6 and we expect to grow these progressively too."

BE11:19am

WAIT! NO! SORRY!

BE11:20am

That's the 2007 buyback release!

11:20 am
BE11:20am

You'll remember 2007, when British Land tried to narrow a discount to NAV immediately before ......... well, before 2008.

BE11:20am

The shares went ........

BE11:20am

11:20 am
PM11:21am

BE11:21am

Tad unfortunate really. Whatever happened to Stephen Hester, British Land Chief Executive?

BE11:21am

Anyway, this time's different.

11:21 am
PM11:21am

(He landed at RSA, poor chap)

BE11:22am

It's now a good idea to use money to try to narrow a NAV that should be there anyway, because commercial property pricing is far from an exact science.

BE11:22am

Brokers are happy.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Here's Numis.

BE11:23am

The logic makes sense given the shares trade on -35% vs NAV and 5.0% yield, with the investment market well-bid by international investors with low cost of capital, and £300m will have only a negligible impact on LTV, leaving sufficient capacity for BLND to continue working on developments. The impact on NAV is immaterial (we estimate c.1.6% on FY17 NAV), but there will be a slightly more positive impact on EPS given the low marginal cost of debt. While we believe the shares will react positively to the announcement, share buybacks in the REIT sector have, historically, not led to a sustained closing of the discount and, being purist, we would rather see capital invested in extracting value from real estate than in financial engineering

BE11:23am

And UBS .........

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Until now, the UK REITs have been reluctant to buy back shares, despite low leverage, wide NAV discounts and limited market opportunities, citing uncertainty and bad experiences with the 2008 buyback programmes. This announcement marks a divergence. We think this move is sensible. We have been noting the disconnect between the listed and direct markets for some time. British Land is selling assets at good prices (including Leadenhall at c25% premium to book value) and can recycle proceeds into its own stock at a 32% discount (UK avg: 20%), with an implied initial yield of c5.6% and dividend yield of 5%. The leverage impact is neutral given the sales programme but the messaging is positive: British Land is taking a view on the market and acting on it.

BE11:24am

And Morgan Stanley, who get quant about this.

BE11:25am

Read across from previous buy back programmes. Last year we analysed 24 property company buy back programmes from the last 15 years in both the UK and continental Europe to estimate the extent to which this impacted stock prices. We make the following observations:
1. The average buy back programme was for 3.4% of shares outstanding. British Land's buy back of £300 million represents 4.8% of current market capitalisation at last night's close, which is not materially different from the typical buy back programme.
2. UK buy backs started on average when UK property stocks were trading at a 35% NAV discount. British Land is trading at a 34% discount to last reported 915p NAV per share as at March, and the UK commercial property market has been resilient since.
3. Historically, on average UK property stocks performed well in absolute and in relative terms during the entire buy back period and during the 12 months after the buy back programme ended.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

And finally, Mike Prew of Jefferies ..........

BE11:26am

....... who's not terribly impressed.

BE11:26am

It’s the 10th anniversary of CEO Stephen 'the equity market's too gloomy' Hester's £500m share buyback at a pre rights price of £14, which was quickly pulled. 2017 looks like a rerun of 2007 and CEO Chris Grigg's gamble of running more leverage risk anticipating an extended real estate cycle is faltering as global bond yields rise. We would sell all the stock we could into this liquidity window.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

We have been waiting for a discount mitigating initiative (most REITs are not explicit) as since March The Leadenhall Building (“Cheesegrater”) was sold for £575m (BL 50% share) with a further £135m of assets sold and a further £88m under offer, but the c.35% LTV still appears excessive given that we think the UK commercial real estate market is about to ‘correct’.

BE11:27am

The shares will probably gain temporary support as Kennedy Wilson’s did but then risk dropping away when BLND completes its £300m buyback, and a more efficient balance sheet management is a special dividend but GPOR and DLN were dismissed by the market.

BE11:28am

I mean, there's always a lot of noise about commercial real estate heading for a correction. Don't think I've had a lunch in about a decade where the conversation hasn't mentioned crane counts and empty newbuild.

11:28 am
PM11:29am

So today's 3% gain in the stock price is ephemeral

British Land Company PLC (BLND:LSE): Last: 623.00, up 19 (+3.15%), High: 625.50, Low: 617.00, Volume: 2.66m
BE11:29am

PM11:33am

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Let me get some Barclays to sum up the figures.

PM11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live, with Bryce Elder

BE11:34am

Within UKPIL, letter volumes were down 6% and revenues down 4%, excluding the direct political party mailings from the elections, but including associated volumes, without which volume would have been down 7%, still a good performance against a tough comp from Q1 FY 17 a year ago. Marketing mail volumes are not reported separately by quarter but were described as being in line with the run rates of last year (we assume -7.5% in our forecasts).

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Parcel volumes were reported up 5% and revenues up 3%. This includes some new inbound Asia cross-border volume, taking advantage of the favourable currency in the UPU rates. Without these new volumes, volumes and revenues would have been up 3% and 2% respectively, but we regard this as volume and revenue that other postal operators have been participating in for some time, so part of the business.

BE11:34am

GLS reported volumes up 5% and revenues up 6%, which, adjusted for the working day effect, were up 9% and 10% respectively. This is a strong performance in our view, a consequence of the better EU economies and the strength of the business model

BE11:35am

Overall, management is clearly pleased with the start to the year and signals no change to the points of guidance given with the FY17 results in May, despite the further weakening in UK business confidence seen since the election. Progress continues to be made with the issues of pensions, pay and productivity and outcomes are expected later in the year.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Was it UBS that was discussing last week how Royal Mail parcels is overpriced?

PM11:35am

not sure

BE11:36am

Or, rather, has too many fixed costs to compete effectively, so the idea that mail order growth will offset letters decline looks ambitious.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Fairly sure that's in the archive somewhere.

BE11:37am

Anyway, UBS keeps its sell.

BE11:37am

On the one hand current overall performance is in-line and share price performance has been weak. However, we believe that UK parcel risks are to the downside, whilst the outlook for UK letters remains weak. We see limited reaction to these results given the additional overhang of the pension situation

BE11:47am

For rocks, rather than fools.

11:47 am
Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 3,414, down 59 (-1.70%), High: 3,450, Low: 3,402, Volume: 931.58k
BE11:48am

Iron ore production a wee bit weak.

BE11:48am

They've been fixing the railroad.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Meaning shipments down 6% yoy, and only up 1% sequentially against the traditionally poor first quarter.

BE11:49am

(Guessing Q1 is usually weak for weather reasons? Never thought to check before.)

BE11:50am

Here comes JPM Caz with a slew of numbers.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

Rio Tinto’s Q2’17 production report is weak, with the key iron ore and copper divisions below JPMe. While
there is likely to be focus on lower 2017 Pilbara shipment guidance (330Mt from 330-340Mt), we do not view
the cut as material given it is only -1.5% from the prior mid point, and our forecast is already 331Mt. Other
production results were mixed, with beats across coal & bauxite, but copper and aluminium lower than JPMe.
Key projects such as Amrum bauxite and Oyu Tolgoi underground remain on schedule. The market may be
somewhat disappointed with iron ore guidance, although this was speculated in the Australian press (AFR), and
consensus should have been at the lower end of the previous 330-340Mt range given the weak Q1. With
ongoing strength across China data, and the shares continuing to look cheap on a valuation basis and with scope
for capital returns at the H1 results, we retain our OW recommendation.

BE11:50am

And Barclays, with fewer numbers.

BE11:50am

A slightly disappointing quarter from Rio leaves the company facing modest earnings downgrades although the impact will be mitigated by stronger iron ore prices relative to consensus, which this production downgrade obviously supports – for example we are assuming $52.5/t CFR in H2 vs. spot at $67/t. We think consensus earnings for FY17 could move down on the production report alone. We also suspect the company could be relatively abstemious in its dividend/cash returns at the H1 results given recent management statements and a dividend policy which favours a 2H weighting to returns – we are assuming a 40% payout ratio and no incremental buyback. Another $500m buyback is possible given RIO has completed 53% of the current $500m program which only commenced on 1 March. Nonetheless Rio’s core attractions of a very strong balance sheet, powerful cashflow generation at current prices, cleanest transfer of that cashflow back to shareholders and valuation support all remain intact. RIO trades on 8.7x spot PE for 2018E, 4.8x EV/EBITDA and 11% FCF yield.

11:50 am
PM11:50am

hmm

PM11:51am

I notice Morgan Stanley are trying to start some sort of face-off

PM11:51am

Between Rio and BHP

11:51 am
PM11:51am

MOST seem to have adopted this stylised prose approach to research

PM11:51am

is this new -- or just new to me?

BE11:52am

Go on........

11:51 am
PM11:52am

Our analysis shows both groups had a poor start to the century.

PM11:52am

But priorities have changed and BHP has the tools to prove it with 38% of market cap in unallocated FCF and a new chairman to guide the process. Sell side skew shows the market already trusts Rio. We rate BHP Plc Overweight.

PM11:52am

Priorities have changed. Our analysis shows BHP and Rio Tinto were equally bad allocators of capital, in particular around acquisitions.

11:52 am
PM11:52am

Etc

PM11:52am

Here, have the rest

PM11:52am

Fortunately, priorities have shifted from outright volume growth to maximising cash flows and better balance between returning cash and re-investing. Our analysis of management incentives, asset quality and financial outlook suggests there are no fundamental reasons to favour Rio Tinto. Nevertheless, sell side consensus is heavily skewed towards Rio with close to 70% Buy ratings on Bloomberg.

11:52 am
PM11:52am

BHP has the tools to change perception and should execute. On our estimates, BHP Plc has 38% excess cash (FCF less dividend) in the next five years on spot, after paying 32% of market cap in dividend, compared to 21% and 34% for Rio Tinto. As a first step, we expect BHP to set a dividend payout ratio of at least 70% for 2HFY17 versus its minimum target of 50% (FY17 dividend of USD0.92 versus Bloomberg consensus of USD0.81). We also expect it to commit to flat investments around USD6.4 billion per year for the next two to three years. And reiterate it will not run cash burning operations including US Onshore but either exit or fix immediately. The appearance of activist investors enhances the spotlight on capital allocation. The new chairman built a reputation focusing on return on capital and cash flow. We see 10% upside potential to BHP Plc. Rio Tinto Plc trades in line with our price target.

PM11:53am

Balance sheets look under-leveraged but debt levels about right, we estimate. On spot earnings both companies look under-leveraged (see Exhibit 2). However, our analysis of leverage ratios based on recent trough earnings scenarios shows current debt levels including provisions are adequate. They would allow both groups to maintain A or A- credit ratings under a trough earnings scenario and to keep flexibility to acquire tier-1 assets or invest at a cycle bottom. The analysis also shows all FCF including disposal proceeds can be distributed to shareholders, in our view. We assume Rio Tinto raises its share buyback from USD0.5 to USD2 billion in our 2017 base case. BHP has not yet resumed share buybacks but we believe has excess cash flows to do so.

PM11:53am

Hurdles that prevent a change in perception at BHP. A return to growth capex, in particular the Jansen potash project, and renewed cash burn at US Onshore are the main risks. The enhanced scrutiny on capital allocation and arrival of a new chairman reduce those risks, in our view.

I may usual place the whole thing later

BE12:05pm

FY17 in line with expectations. But IG’s self-imposed new risk control and appropriateness measures may mean it loses market share in the future. Regulation remains key: FCA proposals are pending the outcome of ESMA discussions (most likely 1H18). IG believes EU/UK regulatory measures could affect around half of group revenue; but likely less given the relative professionalism of its client base (80% of group revenue (ex-US) was generated by less than 9% of clients). We forecast 8% YoY fall in revenue FY19E due to regulation: consistent with a significant revenue hit from less professional clients (20% of 50% = 10%)

The statement reveals that less than 9% of clients generate 80% of IG’s income, with the “vast majority” of these having a trading history which would suggest they should pass the trading experience test for a professional client. In addition, an independent survey found that 15% of IG’s clients have a financial instrument portfolio to pass the test around portfolio size. We believe this is critical, as many of these customers may opt to classify themselves as professionals, and therefore be potentially exempt from possible regulatory changes on leverage limits
.
